meta.title: Servo Motor Training
meta.description: Take the course to learn about how electric servo systems work and how to make an optimal choice of servo motors and drives to achieve a specified performance at minimum cost.

introduction.name: Title
introduction.title: Compro’s Online Servo Motor Analysis and Training Tool

default.name: Fundamentals
default.description: The necessary knowledge of the topics required for understanding the course is presented in this chapter. There is a chance that the user may already be familiar with some of these topics. So, a Pre-test section is provided which will help the user in knowing his / her current understanding of the fundamentals.

default.name: Motion Profiles

items.name: Building a Longer Profile - Absolute moves

default.description: This chapter deals with the formation and analysis of a “Motion Profile” associated with single or multiple axes. It also discusses the approaches to optimise the profile shape and build longer profiles.

default.name: How to Analyse a Rotary Load

items.name: Representing the Instantaneous Torque & Speed Requirements on a Chart

default.description: Motion profiles include calculation of inertia, load torque, RMS torque and so on. This chapter will help the user in calculating the associated parameters and plotting the torque-speed requirements on a chart.

default.name: Servo Motor Selection

items.name: Comparing the Application Requirements to the Motor Ratings

default.description: This chapter will guide the user in comparing the application requirements to motor ratings. The normal requirement is to find the lowest cost solution that will satisfy the specified performance and accuracy requirements.

default.name: Transmission Ratio Optimisation

items.name: Using the T-S Widget to Help with Optimisation

default.description: Motors are often connected to a load mass or load inertia through a transmission system. This may be a gearbox, toothed belt/pulley system or some other transmission mechanism. The effect of transmission ratio as well as the optimization required will be explained in this chapter.

default.name: Linear Loads
default.description: A linear load in this context is a load that moves in a straight line, usually guided by rails or similar constraints. It will be driven either via a mechanism that translates from rotary to linear motion such as a screw-type or a tangential-type drive, or directly by a linear motor. This chapter will examine the screw-type and tangential-type mechanisms.

default.name: Application Examples
default.description: In this chapter, the author will work through some examples that frequently appear in industrial applications. It will discuss about multiple axes involved in real-world examples of servo motors.

default.name: Course Assessment
default.description: After studying the industrial application of servo motors, this chapter will provide numerous questions that deal with tweaking and adjusting of parameters to optimize the cost, reliability and performance of the motors.
